Introduction

This is the documentation for the Prisoner’s Dilemma Simulator, an advanced simulation platform that leverages AI and interactive tools for dynamic strategy exploration and comparative analysis. The simulator provides a comprehensive environment for studying game theory and decision-making through the lens of the classic Prisoner’s Dilemma problem.

Key Features

  • Interactive Strategy Creation - Design and test your own strategies

  • AI-Powered Strategy Interpretation - Natural language processing of strategy descriptions

  • Multiple Game Modes - Tournament, round-robin, and custom match configurations

  • Rich Visualization - Dynamic charts and graphs for strategy performance analysis

  • Built-in Strategy Templates - Pre-defined strategies ranging from basic to advanced

  • Advanced Analysis Tools - Detailed statistics and performance metrics

Getting Started

To get started with the simulator, check out the following sections:

  • Game Logic - Core game mechanics and scoring rules

  • Strategy Interpreter - AI-powered strategy interpretation system

  • Strategy Templates - Pre-defined strategy templates and examples

  • Main Application - Main application interface and configuration

Architecture Overview

The simulator is built with a modular architecture:

  1. Game Logic Module - Implements core game mechanics

  2. Strategy Interpreter - Converts natural language to game logic

  3. Strategy Templates - Provides reusable strategy patterns

  4. Main Application - Handles user interface and coordination

API Reference

For detailed API documentation, refer to:

  • Module Index - Complete list of modules

  • Index - Index of all functions and classes

  • Search Page - Search through documentation

Development

The project uses:

  • Python 3.10+

  • OpenAI GPT for strategy interpretation

  • Streamlit for the web interface

  • Sphinx for documentation

Contributing

We welcome contributions! Please follow these steps:

  1. Check the existing documentation

  2. Follow the coding standards

  3. Add appropriate docstrings

  4. Update tests when adding features
